ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Professor Manley is a kind and relaxed English Professor!I enjoyed the class discussions, and they were accessible given my limited knowledge of Renaissance Poets.Not a bad choice for an elective!
Not excellent, not terrible. Pretty much reading and essays for a poetry class, and we never had lively discussion. But Manley knows a lot, so if you're really into Renaissance it could be great.
It's a introduction to lyric poetry, very broad and covering a lot of authors. I wouldn't take it again because I didn't like the subject, but if it's your thing then it's probably great.
This class gives you a good introduction to Renaissance poetry of all forms. The part about early Renaissance poetry is especially strong.

There's a little bit of a gap in Yale's course offerings when it comes to 16th- and 17th-century poets (not including Shakespeare, obviously), and this survey course does a pretty good job of filling it. Wyatt and Sidney in particular were revelations, as were Marvell, Jonson and Herbert. If you're interested in Renaissance poetry but a little tired with Milton and Shakespeare, this is a good way of getting a look at the lesser-known (though still pretty awesome) poets of that epoch.Professor Manley is incredibly knowledgeable, and he is an able leader of discussions. Generally speaking, it is better to read only a few of the poems he assigns and get to know them well than to skim all of them. (In an ideal world, obviously, everyone would read everything).One more thing: don't be put off by Spenser. I still haven't really understood why he's such a big deal (like everyone else, I suffered bitterly at his hands in English 125), but he only takes up a day or two on the syllabus. Power through!

Manley is very knowledgeable and a pretty cool guy. There's a slightly higher than normal amount of reading and the reading for the first week or two is somewhat boring, but after that it picks up lovely. It's also a very comprehensive course and one you should take, just to explore the canon and develop a god background.

Renaissance Lyric definitely fulfills a pre-1800 requirement. Class discussions were lackluster at best. Minimal preparation was needed for class itself though there were quite a few papers. Take it if you have to.
